Complete Blood Count (CBC): Leukopenia (low white blood cell count), anemia (low red blood cell count), and thrombocytopenia (low platelet count).
Liver Function Tests (ALT, AST, Bilirubi: Elevated levels indicating hepatotoxicity or liver dysfunction.
Renal Function Tests (Creatinine, BUN): Elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels, indicating nephrotoxicity.
Serum Electrolytes (Potassium, Magnesium: Hyperkalemia (high potassium), hypomagnesemia (low magnesium), and hypernatremia (high sodium).
Trough Tacrolimus Levels: Abnormal therapeutic drug levels (too high or too low), impacting efficacy or toxicity.
Blood Glucose: Hyperglycemia, potentially leading to new-onset diabetes after transplantation (NODAT).
Urinalysis: Proteinuria, hematuria, or casts indicating kidney involvement.
Serum LDH: Elevated levels in cases of hemolysis or tissue damage.
C-Reactive Protein (CRP): Reduced levels due to immunosuppressive effects.
Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR): Reduced levels due to suppression of inflammatory responses.
Direct Antiglobulin Test (DAT/Coombs Tes: Positive in cases of drug-induced hemolytic anemia.
Serum Uric Acid: Elevated levels, potentially leading to gout.
Bone Marrow Biopsy: May show hypocellularity in cases of significant cytopenias.
Serum Immunoglobulins (IgG, IgA, IgM): Reduced levels due to immunosuppressive effects.
Parathyroid Hormone (PTH): Elevated levels, particularly in patients with chronic kidney disease.
Pulmonary Function Tests (PFTs): Abnormal results if tacrolimus-induced pulmonary toxicity occurs.
